title-group.article-title: Relationships between retinopathy of prematurity without ophthalmologic intervention and neurodevelopment and vision at 2 years

contrib-group.on-behalf-of: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development Neonatal Research Network

Author Contributions

All authors were involved in each of the following:
Substantial contributions to conception and design, acquisition of data, or analysis and interpretation of data
Drafting the article or revising it critically for important intellectual content; and
Final approval of the version to be published.

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Severe retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is associated with adverse outcomes. Relationships between milder ROP and outcomes have not been defined. We hypothesized that children with ROP stage ≤3 who did not receive ophthalmologic intervention would have worse motor, cognitive, and language skills and more vision abnormalities than children without ROP.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: This was a secondary analysis of a randomized trial evaluating the effects of myo-inositol on ROP in the NICHD Neonatal Research Network. Primary outcomes were Bayley Scales of Infant Development composite scores; secondary outcomes included behavioral difficulties and ophthalmologic measures. Outcomes were compared using adjusted linear or modified Poisson models.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Of 506 children, 173 (34%) had no ROP, 262 (52%) had ROP stage ≤3 without intervention, and 71 (14%) had ROP with intervention. There was no difference in motor, cognitive, or language scores between children with ROP stage ≤3 without intervention and children without ROP. Children with ROP stage ≤3 without intervention had a higher rate of strabismus compared to children without ROP (p=0.040).

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Children with ROP stage ≤3 without intervention did not have adverse neurodevelopmental outcomes at 2 years’ corrected age compared to children without ROP but did have an increased incidence of strabismus.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is a proliferative disorder of the retinal vasculature that occurs in infants born extremely preterm. There is a delay in physiologic retinal vascular development along with vaso-attenuation early on in postnatal life followed by vaso-proliferation with neovascularization later. 1 Severe ROP carries a risk of blindness. Serial screening eye exams are performed for infants at risk of ROP to identify disease that threatens vision and to enable timely intervention. One-third of children born extremely preterm have an eye or visual problem, and the rate of eye or visual problems climbs to over two-thirds when evaluating children who were treated for ROP. 2

More severe forms of ROP for which infants undergo treatment, including laser photocoagulation or anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) administration, are associated with poor neurodevelopmental outcomes. In the ELGAN Study cohort, infants with severe ROP were at increased risk for low scores on the Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development-II (BSID-II) at 24 months after adjusting for risk factors for both ROP and brain injury. 2 In the EXPRESS cohort, Holmstrom et al. found a significant correlation between visual impairment and treated ROP as well as between visual impairment and cognitive disability at 2.5 years. 3 There were major eye or visual problems in 37.9% (147/388) of preterm children born at <27 weeks’ gestation compared to 6.2% of term children at 6.5 years. 4 Among the preterm children, 2.1% were blind, 4.8% were visually impaired by WHO criteria (<20/60), and 8.8% were visually impaired by study criteria (<20/40). In follow-up of preterm infants enrolled in the caffeine for apnea of prematurity trial, Schmidt and colleagues found an association between severe ROP and non-visual disabilities at 5 years of age. 5 The incidence of severe ROP (defined as stage 4 or 5 disease or receipt of retinal therapy) was 6.5%, but only 0.9% of children were bilaterally blind. Of the children with severe ROP, 39.5% had at least 1 non-visual disability at 5 years compared with 15.8% of children without severe ROP (p<0.001). The rates for more than one non-visual disability differed between those with severe ROP (14.9%) and those without severe ROP (2.4%, p<0.001). Motor impairment, cognitive impairment, and severe hearing loss were all more common in children with severe ROP than in those without severe ROP. In a Canadian cohort of preterm infants born at 24-28 weeks’ gestation, cognitive and motor composite scores at 18 months corrected age were negatively impacted in children with severe ROP after adjusting for gestational age and severe brain injury. 6 Finally, ROP treatment modality was not associated with a difference in the combined outcome death or neurodevelopmental impairment in an extremely preterm cohort from the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development Neonatal Research Network. 7 However, the bevacizumab group had a higher mortality and poorer cognitive outcomes than the surgery group in early childhood.

Most of the aforementioned cohorts focused on severe ROP, which despite some variability in definitions, included treated ROP and stage 4 or 5 ROP. Not all ROP requires intervention because less severe (i.e. lower stage) ROP may regress without treatment. We need to better understand the relationship between ROP across the severity spectrum, including lower stage ROP that subsequently regresses, and neurodevelopment in early childhood. The effects of severe forms of major neonatal morbidities endure beyond infancy, but less is known about the effects of less severe forms of the major morbidities, including ROP. This study evaluated the neurodevelopment and vision outcomes of infants with ROP that did not undergo intervention compared to infants without ROP. This is an important knowledge gap to address in order to understand the associations of neonatal ophthalmologic pathology identified during ROP screening examinations and subsequent neurodevelopment and to inform counseling related to ROP across the severity spectrum.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This was a secondary analysis of a randomized controlled trial that evaluated the effects of myo-inositol on ROP risk for children born extremely preterm (<28 weeks’ gestation) and cared for in hospitals of the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development Neonatal Research Network. 8 The institutional review boards at the 18 participating centers approved the trial. Children were born between April 2014-September 2015 and survived at least 12 hours for trial enrollment. Children with major congenital anomalies or syndromes known to potentially affect development were excluded. This clinical trial was discontinued early due to unexpected higher mortality observed in the myo-inositol group. There was no difference in the incidence of any ROP or ROP that met criteria for surgical intervention between the myo-inositol and placebo groups in the trial.

Follow-up evaluation at 22-26 months’ corrected age included administration of the Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development, 3rd Edition (Bayley-III), 9 completion of the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL), 10 and documentation of ophthalmologic examination findings, treatments, and surgeries at serial time points (inpatient or outpatient). Composite motor, cognitive, and language scores on the Bayley-III have a mean score of 100 and a standard deviation (SD) of 15. Children who were untestable due to severe developmental delay were assigned a cognitive score of 54, a composite language score of 46, and a composite motor score of 46. The CBCL consists of 100 behavior-related questions for which the primary caregiver rates problem behaviors on a three-point scale that produces a standardized T-score (mean of 50 and standard deviation of 10). The CBCL can be broken down into seven syndrome scales as well as an internalizing problems score (composed of four syndrome scales), an externalizing problems score (composed of two syndrome scales), a total problems score, and five DSM-oriented scales. The eye examination at 22-26 months’ corrected age, conducted as part of the neurological examination, included assessment for strabismus, nystagmus, roving eye movements, and ability to track 180 degrees.

The participants were categorized into three groups: 1) children with no history of ROP (group 1), 2) children with history of ROP stage ≤3 without ophthalmologic intervention (group 2), and 3) children with history of ROP with ophthalmologic intervention (group 3). Ophthalmologic intervention for ROP included retinal ablation, scleral buckling, vitrectomy, or anti-VEGF therapy. Primary outcomes were the Bayley-III composite scores. Secondary outcomes were non-ROP ophthalmologic outcomes assessed by medical history, neurological examination, and behavioral difficulties as assessed by the CBCL. Medical history included the presence of a diagnosis or suspicion of autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Gross motor function was classified using the gross motor function classification system (GMFCS) where no or mild cerebral palsy refers to level ≤1, moderate CP refers to levels 2 or 3, and severe CP refers to levels 4 or 5. 11 Behavioral difficulties referred to CBCL T-scores for syndrome scales, problem scales (internalizing, externalizing, and total), and DSM-oriented scales. CBCL T-scores <65 were classified as normal, 65-69 as borderline, and ≥70 were classified as clinically significant.

Differences in baseline maternal and neonatal characteristics were analyzed using t-tests for continuous data and chi-square or Fisher exact tests for categorical data. Children with birth weight less than the 10th percentile for gestational age were considered small for gestational age (SGA). 12 Intracranial hemorrhage (ICH) was determined for children who had cranial sonography performed within 28 days of birth, with findings classified by Papile criteria. 13 Comparisons were made between children with no history of ROP (group 1) vs. children with ROP stage ≤3 without intervention (group 2) as well as between children with ROP stage ≤3 without intervention (group 2) vs. children with history of ROP with intervention (group 3). The Bayley-III primary outcome measures were compared using a generalized linear model including the ROP group and adjusted for baseline covariates (maternal race, gestational age, sex, and severe IVH) and with study center as a random effect. A sensitivity analysis was performed by adjusting results for myo-inositol randomization group; however, results did not change. Adjusted risk differences with 95% confidence intervals and p-values were reported. For the primary outcomes, a Bonferroni correction was used to adjust for multiple comparisons. Secondary outcome measures were compared using generalized linear or modified Poisson models, as described for the primary outcome measures. Adjusted risk differences or relative risks with 95% confidence intervals and p-values were reported; however, Bonferroni correction was not used to adjust for multiple comparisons for the secondary outcomes due to the exploratory nature of these analyses. All statistical analyses were performed with SAS version 9.4 (SAS Institute Inc.).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: There were 638 infants enrolled in the myo-inositol trial, of whom 546 (86%) survived to final ROP status (up to 55 weeks’ postmenstrual age); 506 (93%) survivors were evaluated at 22-26 months’ corrected age (Fig. 1). There were 173 (34%) children with no history of ROP (group 1), 262 (52%) children with history of ROP stage ≤3 without intervention (group 2), and 71 (14%) children with history of ROP with intervention (group 3). Maternal race differed between children with no ROP and children with ROP without intervention while maternal education differed between children with ROP without intervention and children with ROP with intervention (Table 1). Gestational age and birth weight differed between children with no ROP and those with ROP without intervention as well as between children with ROP without intervention and those with ROP with intervention. Neonatal morbidities of patent ductus arteriosus, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, and spontaneous intestinal perforation were more common in children with ROP without intervention compared to children with no ROP (Table 2). Intracranial hemorrhage, periventricular leukomalacia, late onset sepsis, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, and necrotizing enterocolitis were more common in children with history of ROP with intervention than children with history of ROP without intervention.

The adjusted mean Bayley-III motor, cognitive, and language composite scores did not differ for children with ROP without intervention compared to children with no ROP (Table 3). The incidence of an abnormal neurological examination, cerebral palsy, or gross motor function classification level ≥2 did not differ significantly for children with ROP without intervention compared to children with no ROP. Medical history of diagnosis or suspicion of ASD did not differ for children with ROP without intervention and children with no ROP. The CBCL T-scores were similar for children with ROP without intervention and children with no history of ROP with the exception of aggressive behavior, attention deficit/hyperactivity problems, and externalizing problems. In each of these domains, the T-score differed by less than 2 points for the groups. The T-score was statistically lower (better) for children with ROP without intervention than children without ROP. However, the majority of children in both groups had T-scores within the normal range for these CBCL domains (Supplemental Table S1). Regarding ophthalmologic outcomes, children with ROP without intervention were more likely than children without ROP to have strabismus (aRR 2.12, 95% CI 1.04 to 4.32) (Table 4). There was no difference in the incidence of nystagmus (aRR 0.54, 95% CI 0.22 to 1.33), roving eye movements (aRR 0.73, 95% CI 0.14 to 3.85), inability to track 180 degrees (aRR 0.84, 95% CI 0.28 to 2.56), eye surgery for non-ROP indication (aRR 1.02, 95% CI 0.31 to 3.33), or being prescribed corrective lenses (aRR 0.87, 95% CI 0.34 to 2.21).

In contrast, the mean Bayley-III motor, cognitive, and language composite scores all were lower for children with ROP with intervention compared to children with ROP stage ≤3 without intervention (motor 74.65 ± 2.41 vs. 83.01 ± 1.93, p=0.013; cognitive 77.13 ± 2.07 vs. 84.98 ± 2.15, p=0.001; and language 72.71 ± 2.75 vs. 79.82 ± 2.09, p=0.007) (Table 3). Children with ROP with intervention were more likely to have a gross motor function classification level ≥2 and to have hearing loss than children with ROP without intervention (25.4% vs. 7.5% and 14.3% vs. 1.6%, respectively). The incidences of abnormal neurological examination and cerebral palsy did not differ significantly for children with ROP with intervention compared to children with ROP without intervention. Medical history of diagnosis or suspicion of ASD appeared to differ for children with ROP with intervention and children with ROP stage ≤3 without intervention (p=0.044). Behavioral problems as assessed by the CBCL T-scores did not differ between these two groups. Additionally, the majority of children in both groups had T-scores that fell within the normal range (Supplemental Table S1). For ophthalmologic outcomes, children with ROP stage ≤3 without intervention were more likely to have normal visual acuity than children with ROP with intervention (89.5% vs. 49.3%, p<0.001). There was no difference in the incidence of strabismus (aRR 1.31, 95% CI 0.66 to 2.63), nystagmus (aRR 4.09, 95% CI 1.00 to 16.81), roving eye movements (aRR 1.21, 95% CI 0.04 to 40.40), inability to track 180 degrees (aRR 2.29, 95% CI 0.86 to 6.07), or eye surgery for non-ROP indication (aRR 2.34, 95% CI 0.87 to 6.27) for children with ROP with intervention compared to children with ROP without intervention (Table 4). Five children were blind with some functional vision, 4 of whom had ROP without intervention and 1 of whom had ROP with intervention. Two children were blind with no functional vision, both of whom had ROP with intervention.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This investigation addressed the knowledge gap in understanding the relationship between ROP that regresses without intervention and neurodevelopment. For children born extremely preterm, those with ROP stage ≤3 that regressed without intervention were no more likely to have adverse neurodevelopmental outcomes at 2 years’ corrected age than children born extremely preterm without a history of ROP. Outcomes assessed included motor, cognitive, and language skills as well as neurological examination, cerebral palsy, and hearing loss. While parents of children with history of ROP without intervention reported fewer difficulties in the domains of aggressive behavior, attention deficit/hyperactivity problems, and externalizing problems than parents of children with no history of ROP, both groups’ T-scores fell within the normal range. Regarding ophthalmologic outcomes, children born extremely preterm with history of ROP stage ≤3 without intervention were more likely to have strabismus than children born extremely preterm without a history of ROP. There were four children with ROP stage ≤3 without intervention who were blind with some functional vision at follow-up. This is a clinically significant outcome but given the small number of patients we were unable to evaluate for a difference between groups. Ophthalmologic follow-up is necessary for extremely preterm infants, including those who did not undergo intervention for ROP, given the possibility of vision impairment.

By contrast, children who underwent an ophthalmologic intervention for ROP had worse neurodevelopmental and vision outcomes at 2 years’ corrected age than did children born extremely preterm who did not undergo an intervention for ROP. While the incidence of cerebral palsy or behavioral problems was similar between the two groups, children with ROP who received an intervention were more likely to have worse gross motor function and to have hearing loss compared to children with history of ROP stage ≤3 without intervention. Regarding ophthalmologic outcomes, children born extremely preterm with history of ROP with intervention had worse visual acuity than children with history of ROP stage ≤3 without intervention. Although the two groups did not differ in the incidence of other ophthalmologic outcomes, the difference for the incidence of nystagmus approached statistical significance with nearly 13% of children with ROP with intervention affected by nystagmus compared to just over 2% of children with ROP without intervention (aRR 4.09, 95% CI 1.00 to 16.81).

Data on children with blindness suggests that we should not look at vision outcomes in isolation from other neurodevelopmental outcomes. De Verdier et al. evaluated disability among 150 children affected by blindness in Sweden. The most common etiology of blindness in the cohort was ROP (34 children, 24%). 14 There was a high incidence of coexisting non-visual disability, mostly commonly intellectual disability, with 54% of children having more than one additional disability. One possible pathophysiologic explanation for worse developmental outcomes is diminished visual acuity. Alternatively, there may be common pathways leading to impaired neural and vascular development in the brain and retina. Altered white matter maturation is another possible explanation for altered neurodevelopment in children affected by ROP. 15 White matter maturation in the posterior limb of the internal capsule, external capsule, and optic radiations, regions critical for visual and motor pathways, is delayed in extremely preterm infants with severe ROP. 6 Sveinsdottir et al. evaluated ROP (any stage), brain volumes at term-equivalent age, and developmental outcomes at 2 years corrected age in 52 children born preterm. 16 They found that children with ROP had smaller unmyelinated white matter and cerebellar volumes and lower BSID-II scores than children without ROP after adjusting for perinatal risk factors.

Because ROP occurs on a spectrum and because there may be shared physiology for brain and retinal development, it is important to understand neurodevelopment and ophthalmologic outcomes of children affected by less severe forms of ROP. This investigation adds to the literature evidence that milder forms of ROP, defined as ROP stage ≤3 without intervention, are not associated with poorer neurodevelopment among children born extremely preterm. Multiple studies have shown that severe ROP is associated with worse neurodevelopmental and ophthalmologic outcomes in affected children. 3-6 In one cohort of 152 extremely preterm infants with normal cranial ultrasounds, Sampath and colleagues found the occurrence of any ROP to be a postnatal risk factor associated with adverse developmental outcomes at 5 years. 17 Similarly, follow-up at 5.5 years of children enrolled in the multicenter trial of cryotherapy for ROP identified an association between the functional status and ROP severity. Any ROP had a relative risk of 2.27 (95% CI 1.26-4.07) for scoring in the lowest functional status, which was described as severe disability. While the focus of the trial was on those children with threshold disease (five or more contiguous or 8 cumulative clock hours of ROP stage ≥3 in either zone 1 or 2), the investigators were insightful in reporting the outcomes of those with less severe forms of ROP. 18

The current study identified differential neurodevelopment of young children with history of ROP with ophthalmologic intervention compared to children with history of ROP without intervention. In contrast, Molloy and colleagues evaluated visual processing, visual learning, visual-motor integration, intelligence quotient, and academic achievement in 180 adolescents born extremely preterm. 19 The adolescents were grouped by ROP status into severe ROP (stage 3 or greater) versus no or mild ROP (stage 1 or 2). After controlling for perinatal risk, only visual acuity scores differed between adolescents with history of severe ROP (stage ≥3) and those with history of mild ROP (stage 1 or 2).

Strengths of this study include the multicenter design, availability of ROP examination and intervention data from the inpatient and outpatient settings, and comprehensive neurologic follow-up at 22-26 months’ corrected age. The eye examination at 2 years, conducted as part of the neurological examination, included assessment for strabismus, nystagmus, roving eye movements, and ability to track 180 degrees. A limitation of the study was that visual acuity was obtained by history, either by parent report or review of the medical record, at the 2-year follow-up visit. There were not confirmatory ophthalmologic examinations to validate parent report of vision. There may have been variability in reporting the need for corrective lenses as well as a potential for referral bias to outpatient ophthalmology follow-up for those infants who underwent intervention for ROP. An additional limitation was the lack of postnatal growth evaluation; postnatal growth may also relate to both the risk of neurodevelopmental impairment and to the risk of ROP. Finally, the young age of follow-up may be a limitation with respect to assessment of neurodevelopment and vision outcomes. At two years, children are not yet able to be evaluated for executive function and academic achievement, two domains in which children born extremely preterm may manifest difficulties later in childhood. 20,21 Long-term follow-up from the multicenter trial of cryotherapy for ROP revealed a gradual increase in unfavorable ocular structural outcomes between 1 year and 15 years for those affected by more severe forms of ROP. 22 Results for ASD must be interpreted with caution given that the information was obtained by history and the small number of children with ASD in each group.

This study informs ROP-related counseling for clinicians who care for extremely preterm infants in the neonatal intensive care unit as well as in outpatient follow-up. Neurodevelopmental outcomes were similar for children born extremely preterm with history of ROP stage ≤3 without intervention and those without ROP. Follow-up with ophthalmology is important for children born preterm with ROP stage ≤3 without intervention given the higher incidence of strabismus compared to those without ROP as well as the occurrence of blindness with some functional vision in a few children at follow-up. In contrast, both neurodevelopment, including motor, cognitive, and language skills, and visual acuity are more problematic for those children who underwent ophthalmologic intervention for ROP compared to those with less severe forms of ROP without intervention. Anticipatory counseling pertaining to ophthalmologic and developmental outcomes is indicated for all children born extremely preterm. This study informs how counseling may be tailored by the severity of ROP. Specifically, the neurodevelopmental outcomes of children with ROP without intervention do not differ notably from the outcomes of children born extremely preterm with no history of ROP at two years. Longer-term follow-up is needed to fully understand the associations between ROP without ophthalmologic intervention, neurodevelopment, and vision since neurodevelopment and vision difficulties may manifest later in childhood.

fn.p: Risk differences are calculated for continuous variables, relative risks are calculated for binary variables. Risk differences and relative risks adjusted for gestational age, sex, mother’s race, and severe IVH (grades III-IV) unless otherwise noted.

fn.p: Four subscales contribute to the Internalizing Problems scale: emotionally reactive, anxious/depressed, somatic complaints, and withdrawn.

fn.p: Two subscales contribute to the Externalizing Problems scale: attention problems and aggressive behavior.

fn.p: Three subscales contribute to the CBCL Dysregulation Profile: attention problems, aggressive behavior, and anxious/depressed. A combined score of 180 or greater is considered clinically significant.

fn.p: Relative risks adjusted for gestational age, sex, mother's race, and severe IVH (grades III-IV) unless otherwise noted.

fn.p: Categorized as present if present in either eye.

fn.label: d
fn.p: Participant categorized as having normal visual acuity if normal vision in both eyes. If one eye has normal visual acuity and the other has a vision abnormality, the participant is categorized according to the abnormality. If both eyes have a vision abnormality, the participant is categorized according to the less severe abnormality.

fn.label: e
fn.p: Relative risks are not calculated due to small cell counts.

list-item.p: This study addresses a gap in the literature regarding the relationship between milder forms of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) that regress without intervention and neurodevelopment and vision outcomes.

Children with a history of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) stage ≤3 without intervention have similar neurodevelopmental outcomes at 2 years’ corrected age as children born extremely preterm without a history of ROP and better outcomes than children with a history of ROP with ophthalmologic intervention.
Counseling about likely neurodevelopment and vision outcomes for children born extremely preterm with a history of ROP may be tailored based on the severity of ROP.
